M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209, §§ 37–38, a custody judgment may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the previous judgment and where the modification is in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 209, \u00a7\u00a7 37\u201338.proposition: Under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209, §§ 37–38, a custody judgment may be modified upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the previous judgment and where the modification is in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6 to act in furtherance of the welfare of the child.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The Plaintiff believes that the existing custody order no longer serves the best interests of the child, as defined by G.L. c. 208, § 31, and that a modification providing for primary physical custody with the Plaintiff, with parenting time for the Defendant consistent with his medical limitations, is now necessary.

Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 864.raw_text: Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 864 (2021)
Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 864.proposition: See Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 864 (2021) (health deterioration and capacity to supervise child warranted reconsideration of prior custody order).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: See Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The claimed proposition is incomplete and merely lists two citations without identifying any specific legal principle. Yannas clearly discusses standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth and joint custody, but without knowing what precise rule the proposition is asserting (e.g., a "real advantage" test, best-interests standard, etc.), it is impossible to say that this citation supports it. Thus, I cannot reliably match the opinion to the unspecified proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that "[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders." The words "upon cause shown" mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these "best interests" are to be determined.

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: See Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985); Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The user’s claimed proposition only shows that Vilakazi is being cited alongside Yannas with a pinpoint to Yannas, but does not state the underlying rule. From the opinion, Vilakazi clearly reaffirms the fundamental Massachusetts principle that custody determinations are governed by the best interests/welfare of the child and are committed to the probate judge’s discretion, which is the kind of foundational custody principle Yannas later relies on and cites. Thus, as a general authority on best‑interests‑of‑the‑child and judicial discretion in custody, Vilakazi does support the type of proposition for which it is typically paired with Yannas.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.proposition: Courts have held that when an existing custody order no longer adequately protects the welfare of the minor child, modification is required.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and the application of a best-interests standard where parents share joint physical and legal custody. It does involve a complaint for modification, but the court does not articulate or apply a rule that a custody order must be modified whenever it no longer adequately protects the child’s welfare. The focus is on whether removal should be authorized, not on a general principle that modification is required when an existing order inadequately protects the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183 (20.relevant_excerpt: "When the mother informed the father of her intention to move to New Hampshire, the father refused to consent to removal of the children from the Commonwealth and filed a complaint for *181modification of the divorce decree in the Probate and Family Court seeking, among other things, sole physical custody ... After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court."

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The presence of a parent’s chronic illness that materially affects caregiving capacity may justify modification where the schedule endangers or burdens a child.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does not involve a parent’s chronic illness or any health-related limitation on caregiving capacity; it focuses on relocation, improper use of a temporary custody order, and the absence of any material and substantial change in circumstances to justify modifying custody. The court actually rejects the asserted changes (work schedule, move, temporary arrangement) as insufficient to warrant modification. Therefore, this case cannot be cited as authority that a parent’s chronic illness burdening a child may justify modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995. To the contrary, the findings reflect that the mother is a loving and appropriate caretaker.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6 to act in furtherance of the welfare of the child.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses standards for best-interest determinations, deference to trial judges, and DSS’s discretion in custody and adoption matters, but it does not mention G.L. c. 215, § 6 or describe any broad equitable powers of the court under that statute. The case is framed entirely in terms of G.L. c. 119 and c. 210 and ordinary custody/adoption review standards, not Probate and Family Court equitable jurisdiction. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … It is for this reason … that our attitude toward a trial judge’s decision in a custody appeal is one of substantial deference.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that stability, safety, and the child’s emotional well‑being are key factors in assessing best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the best‑interests standard and emphasizes that maintaining a stable, continuous caregiving arrangement is itself a major component of a child’s welfare. It highlights the benefits of stability and continuity with the primary caregiver and warns that unnecessary disruption of an adequate status quo increases the risk of harm to the child, thereby tying stability and safety directly to the child’s overall well‑being as key best‑interests factors. While it does not use the precise phrase “emotional well‑being,” that concept is clearly encompassed in its discussion of harm, welfare, and continuity.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that stability, safety, and the child’s emotional well‑being are key factors in assessing best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion directly frames the custody analysis around the impact of domestic violence on the child, emphasizing the child’s need for physical security and the psychological harm from witnessing abuse. The court requires explicit findings on “the effect of the violence on the child” when determining custody, which reflects that safety, the stability of a non‑violent home, and the child’s emotional well‑being are key best‑interests factors. Although the words “stability” and “emotional well‑being” are not used as a formula, the reasoning clearly centers those concepts.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We endorse the Appeals Court’s commitment to the propositions that physical force within the family is both intolerable and too readily tolerated, and that a child who has been either the victim or the spectator of such abuse suffers a distinctly grievous kind of harm. … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.raw_text: Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 272, 279–80 (2009)
Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.proposition: The Plaintiff’s requested modification comports with the statutory and judicial principle that custody should ensure safety and consistent parental care.
Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on evidentiary requirements and judicial conduct in temporary custody hearings, not on articulating a general statutory or judicial principle that custody modifications must ensure safety and consistent parental care. While it mentions the need to protect children from serious abuse or neglect, the holding is about improper reliance on evidence not in the record and the standard for emergency removal, not about endorsing a specific requested modification as comporting with such a principle. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the proposition stated.
Care and Protection of Zita, 455 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: "When we strip from the decision below the information contained in the petition, which was not in evidence, and information the judge may have learned from the earlier care and protection cases, also not in evidence, we are left with grave concerns that the department fell short of meeting its statutory obligation of demonstrating that the newborn infant was in 'immediate danger of serious abuse or neglect' and that 'immediate removal' was necessary to protect her. Care & Protection of Robert, 408 Mass. 52, 57 (1990)."

Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795, 799 (.proposition: The Plaintiff’s requested modification comports with the statutory and judicial principle that custody should ensure safety and consistent parental care.
Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795, 799 (.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards of proof and appellate review in care-and-protection/custody cases, not with the substantive statutory or judicial principle that custody orders should ensure safety and consistent parental care. While the facts involve safety concerns (possible sexual abuse) and parental unfitness, the court’s holding focuses on evidentiary sufficiency and deference to trial findings, not on articulating or applying a general principle that a requested modification must ensure safety and consistent care. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Custody of Eleanor, 414 Mass. 795, 799 (.relevant_excerpt: “Appellate review in custody appeals is not done to assess the evidence de nova, but rather to determine whether the judge’s findings were clearly erroneous and whether they proved parental unfitness by clear and convincing evidence.”
